body.p:
Maysville Kentucky
January 14th 1864
To His Excellency
Gov Bramlette
Dear Sir; The undersigned members of the Board of Council of this city, respectfully submit for your consideration the following statement

There are a large number of licensed establishments in this City for the sale of spiritous liquors, and quite a large number of persons who sell liquor without license. These people are occassionally convicted and fined for a violation of the Laws and ordinances of the City. As a general rule they claim to be innocent and get up a petition signed by their friends, praying the Board of Council to remit the fine, as we have a right to do by law. We remit such fines as ought to be remitted. Being familiar with the circumstances, or in a position where we can arrive at the truth we occassionally refuse to pardon an offender, who straitway sends a petition to the Executive of the State, and obtains a discharge from the fine imposed, before the City officials have any notice that such petition is pending We have therefore determined to request your Excellency not to remit any fine imposed by the Mayor of this City without first giving this Board an opportunity to advise you fully as to the truth of the particular case presented. We are much more apt to remit fines that ought not to be remitted than to pursue the
opposite course We can always to accurately informed as to the facts of each case and we feel satisfied that we treat each case fairly The Law must be executed to some extent, but it has become so common to obtain at the hands of the state Executive, remittances of fines that they are seldom imposed

We therefore respectfully and earnestly petition your Excellency not to remit any fine without giving us an opportunity to advise you fully in relation to the application which we pledge ourselves to do

Respectfully
W. H. McGranaghan, President
T. C Campbell
Henry Rudy
W F. Wilson
D Clark
Jos Wallingford
John Brasee
James Smith
Jos. F. Brodrick
Milton Culbertson
W H Wise
